channel.title: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related
channel.description: I have a programming class coming up next semester. Programming 2, I'm guessing we are continuing on Visual Basic : ( One of the most worthless programming languages unless you need to a quick program in which you want a button that outputs the sum of 1+1 into a text box with Size 40 Calibri font. So really what I'm getting at is what should I be using, Windows 7 or Windows XP. I only have a RC of Windows 7 which expires in the coming months and I haven't found a solid way to bypass this (yet). So I'm thinking about just installing Windows XP back onto my computer. I think XP would be easier for a programming environment but fuck if I know I haven't programmed in forever (if you even consider VB a real programming language). So 7 or XP TELL ME NOW!

item.title: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related

item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:11, topic:326899”]What does RTM mean, and does this version require a key or activation hack; what is all involved with it?[/quote]requires serial but you can bypass it using an app like 7loader

Read full topic

item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

It really shouldn’t make too much of a difference. Use whichever OS you are comfortable with.

item.title: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

What is RTM?

It stands for Release to Manufacturers. RTM means that the code for Windows will be finalized and partners will receive it and start preparations to launch new PCs.

http://www.ithinkdiff.com/windows-7-rtm-faq/

Read full topic

item.title: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

Its really up to you, windows 7 (imo) is very well build OS with little to no bugs compared to vista. The only problem I might see as mopar said is the compatibility issue, although you can right click the exe and change the compatibilty…but im not 100% sure it would work.

Also, it depends on the type of hardware that you have, mostly all the hardware that are in computers are compatable with xp but the new models eaither dont have drivers for older OS’ or were meant to work only on DX10 OS.

PS, you can get a fully cracked version of win 7 from torrent sites.

Read full topic
item.source: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related

item.description:

i read through it fast so i might’ve missed the point but there is no real reason for it to be programming related and put here… maybe you’re putting forth effort in trying to get help from the oh-so-umm… knowledgable programmers of moparisthebest??

Read full topic
item.source: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related

item.title: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Yeah probably XP would be best. Its just easier for me because I’ve used it for so long. I started with XP when I first started getting interested in computers. We are learning VB6 in school but what I’ve been using is VB Express 2008. http://www.microsoft.com/express/Windows/ The syntax is pretty much the same. We were suppose to be learning Java, but I guess that’s not on the curriculum which makes me unhappy because now I have to go back and review VB to be as ready as the kids who had it last semester.

Read full topic
item.source: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related

item.title: Windows 7 or Windows XP - Programming Related
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I guess, regardless of anything else, if you only have an RC of 7 that expires in a few days you must go with XP.

I also don’t know how Visual Basic 6 will get along with 7, perhaps you should do a google to see if people can/do use it.

Read full topic
